name: End of Summer Dinner Party
desc:
This is my online recipe archive. http://richcooks.blogspot.com/2012/05/trello-for-recipes.html

The finished recipes are ordered by how frequently I cook them (approximately).

cards.desc: Chicken, sausage, shrimp.  A big one, not too spicy, very good.  Spending time on the roux paid off.  There were a few key points.  When the roux starts to chunk up, you need to pay more attention, when it hits dark penny color, the veggies go in.  When the veggies start to grease out of their little roux sweaters, the hot stock goes in.
cards.name: Gumbo

cards.desc:
good choices for condiments include diced fresh tomatoes, diced avocado, sliced scallions, chopped red onion, chopped cilantro leaves, sour cream and shredded Monterey Jack or chedder cheese.  The flavor of the chili improves with age; if possible, make it a day or up to five days in adcance and reheat before serving,  Leftovers can be frozen for up to a month.


2 tablespoons vegetable or corn oil
2 medium onions, chopped fine(about 2 cups)
1 red bell pepper, cut into 1/2 inch cubes
6 medium garlic cloves, minced or pressed through garlic press(about 2 tablespoons)
1/4 cup chili powder
1 tablespoon ground cumin
2 teaspoons ground coriander
1 teaspoon red pepper flakes
1 teaspoon dried oregano
1/2 teaspoon cayenne pepper
2 pounds 85 percent lean ground beef
2 cans(16 oz each) dark red kidney beans, drained and rinsed
2 15oz cans hominy
1 can(29 oz) diced tomatoes, with juice
1 can (28 oz) tomato puree
1 10 oz pg frozen sweet kernel corn
salt
2 limes cut into wedges

1. Heat oil in a large heavy-bottomed nonreactive Dutch oven over medium heat until shimmering but not smoking, 3 to 4 minutes.  Add onions, bell pepper, garlic, cumin, coriander, pepper flakes, oregano, and cayenne; cook, stirring occasionally, until vegetable are softened and beginning to brown, about 10 minutes.
 
2. Add tomatoes. Go to town with a potato masher to break up the tomatoes.

3. In a second pot, heat 1 tbs oil to just over medium heat. Add Oreo-sized chunks of ground beef to the oil and cook like mini-burgers, well-spaced, until browned. As they brown, transfer to the other pot and add more mini-burgers. With the last batch, add the chili powder and cook briefly. Dump everything in the main pot.  Use the potato masher to break up the meat oreos

4. Then add beans, hominy, corn and 1/2 tsp salt; bring to boil, then reduce heat to low and simmer, covered, stirring occasionally, for 45 minutes, stirring every 10 minutes or so..

Remove cover and continue to simmer for one hour longer, stirring occasionally (if chili begins to stick to bottom of pot, stir in 1/2 cup water and continue to simmer), until beef is tender and chili is dark, rich, and slightly thickened.  Adjust seasoning with additional salt.
cards.name: Chili

cards.desc:
People always add dill to homemade ranch dressing for some reason. It never tastes right. This is basically just flavored by soaking with onion and garlic, which never make it into the final product. If you don't have fresh herbs, that's fine. Leave them out or substitute dried. They're really just for the flecks.

##Ingredients
1 cup mayo  
1 cup buttermilk  
1 small onion, roughly chopped  
2 cloves garlic, skin-on, crushed with flat of knife  
Pinch of dried oregano  
1/4 tsp salt
1/4 tsp white pepper

Chopped chives and or parsley

##Method
Stir everything except the fresh herbs until well-combined.
Let sit overnight or several hours. Strain out solids and discard. Add chopped fresh herbs.
cards.name: Ranch Dressing

cards.desc:
Shrimp and Chicken in Scotch Whisky

This is excellent served with 4 chopped leeks that have been simmered until tender in a very little chicken broth, then just before serving add 1/2 cup mascapone.  Place this as a garnish just before serving on top of the dish. 

3/4 pound medium peeled shrimp  
3/4 pound chicken tenders  
1/2 stick butter  
1/4 cup olive oil  
1 white onion very finely chopped  
1 clove garlic crushed  
1 large tomatoes, peeled, seeded and finely chopped  
Salt and black pepper  
Cayenne pepper to taste  
A little dried tarragon (optional)  
1/4 cup Scotch whisky  
1/3 cup dry white wine  
1 teaspoon cornstarch  
1/4 cup cream  
1 egg yolk  

Melt the butter in a pan and add the oil. Fry the onion and garlic until just transparent. Add the shrimp, chicken, chopped tomatoes and all the seasonings. Cook for a few minutes.
Pour the Scotch into the pan and set alight. Add the wine and simmer for 5 minutes. Remove the shrimp and chicken from the pan and add the cream and cornstarch (mixed together first) to the pan juices and stir vigorously over medium heat until it comes to a boil. Remove from heat and immediately add the slightly beaten egg yolk. Add back the prawns and chicken and serve immediately.

Serve with Basmati Rice
cards.name: Shrimp & Chicken in Scotch Whisky

cards.desc:
This was my favorite thing they had at the Raw Food Station at Google New York.

#Ingredients:

2 heads Cauliflower  
2 English Cucumber, split, seeded, chopped  
2 pints Cherry Tomato, cut in   
1 Red Onion, diced  
1 bunch Parsley, chopped  
 cup Mint, chopped  
3 Garlic Cloves, minced  
 cup Olive Oil  
 cup fresh Lemon Juice  
Salt & Pepper to taste  

#Method
Cut cauliflower heads into florets, then pulse in a food processor or blender until resembling the consistency of bulgur.

Combine all ingredients in a mixing bowl. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Chill until serving.
cards.name: Cauliflower tabbouleh

cards.desc:
4 cups baby red potatoes, cut in small pieces

1/2 cup green bell pepper, finely diced

1/4 cup red onion, finely diced

3 scallions, diced

1 tsp dijon mustard

1 tbsp extra virgin olive oil

1 tbsp red wine vinegar

1 tbsp reduced fat mayonnaise

salt and fresh pepper

Boil potatoes in salted water until soft, approx 10 minutes. Drain and let cool.

While the potatoes are boiling, combine red onion, green pepper, mustard, olive oil, vinegar and mayonnaise and season with salt and pepper. Mix well and let the flavors marinade while the potatoes cook. Once the potatoes are done and cool, mix into the bowl and add scallions and additional salt and pepper to taste. Serve room temperature or refrigerate until ready to serve.
cards.name: Red Potato Salad

cards.desc:
http://www.amazon.fr/Fondre-plaisir-cuisine-originelle-bien-%C3%AAtre/dp/2733909614/

Biscuits Croquants Poivre et Noisette

- 100 grams (3/4 cup) whole hazelnuts
- 200 grams (1 2/3 cups) whole wheat flour (I used a mix of T65 and T110)
- 70 grams (2/3 cup) spelt flakes (or other old-fashioned rolled grains, such as oats)
- 120 grams (1/2 cup + 2 tablespoons) unrefined cane sugar
- 1 teaspoon baking soda
- a good pinch salt
- 1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper (substitute 1/4 teaspoon curry powder or 1/2 teaspoon good cinnamon)
- 130 grams (1/2 cup + 2 tablespoons) butter, chilled and finely diced
- 2 tablespoons rose water, orange flower water, or just plain water, plus a little more as needed

Toast the hazelnuts in a dry skillet until fragrant. If the hazelnuts are still in their papery husks, you can remove some of it by rubbing them in a clean dishcloth while they're still warm; you don't have to, though. Let cool and chop roughly (see tip above).

Combine the hazelnuts with the rest of the dry ingredients, from flour to pepper, in a medium mixing bowl. Stir with a wooden spoon until blended.

Add the diced butter and rub it into the dry ingredients with your fingers or a wire pastry blender until the mixture resembles coarse meal. Add the rose water and stir it in until the dough comes together just enough that you can gather it in two balls. If it's not enough, add a little more rose water, little by little, until the dough reaches the desired consistency.

Cover the bowl with a dishcloth and set aside somewhere cool for 1 hour.

Preheat the oven to 150C (300F) and line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Shape the dough into balls a bit larger than walnuts, flatten them slightly, and place them on the prepared baking sheet, leaving them a little elbowroom to expand.

Bake for 25 minutes, until golden and set. Let stand for 5 minutes on the baking sheet before transfering to a rack to cool completely.
cards.name: Hazelnut & Black Pepper Sables

cards.desc:
Adapted from Fergus Henderson Appeared NY Times 12/27/2006

2 T butter  
2 T flour  
1 T mustard powder (or to taste)  
1/2 t cayenne or to taste  
3/4 c strong dark beer  
2 T Worcestershire sauce
1 lb. Cheddar, Double Gloucester or other semi-hard cheese, grated  
4-8 pieces lightly toasted bread

##Method

Put butter in saucepan over medium heat and, as it melts, stir in flour. Continue to cook, stirring occasionally, until golden brown and very fragrant, 3-5 mins. Stir in mustard and cayenne, then whisk in beer and Worcestershire sauce

When mix is uniform, turn heat to low and stir in cheese, again stirring until smooth. Remove from heat and pour into a broad container to set. Can be refrigerated for up to a day at this point.

Spread mixture thickly on toast and put under broiler until bubbly and edges of toast are crisp. Serve immediately.

4-6 servings
cards.name: Welsh Rarebit

cards.desc:
I've loved pate since I was a toddler. Here's why:

#Ingredients
8 ounces chicken livers, soaked in a little milk for 1 hour
1 onion, chopped
2 cloves garlic, chopped
4 ounces butter
4 slices bacon
 cup chopped mushrooms
Lots of black pepper
 teaspoon mixed dried herbs
2 tablespoons good Cognac

#Method
Cook the onions, garlic and bacon until a warm brown. Add the mushrooms and cook a little.
Wash and drain the chicken livers and pat dry.  Add the chicken livers to the bacon. Cover and cook for a couple of minutes - do not over cook. Season well and add the cognac and cook a little longer. Remove from the heat and let the butter melt in. Now puree and extra long time for a creamy texture.  Adjust seasoning again if necessary - secret is lots of black pepper.
cards.name: Di's Chicken Liver Pate

cards.desc:
I chop the kale into 1 inch pieces, drizzle in olive oil, sea salt and lemon zest and bake at 450 for like 20 mins 

 -- liz
cards.name: Kale chips

cards.desc: http://reciperenovator.com/special-diets/vegan/cheese-how-to-make-tofu-misozuke/
cards.name: Tofu Misozuke

cards.desc:
My friend Cristin, from Queens, NY, stunned me one night at Bamonte's, a weapons-grade Italian joint in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. She ordered off-menu on her first time there. She asked if they had Chicken *Giamboc*, and they dutifully delivered a "jumble" of roasted chicken, sausage, peppers, onions and potatoes.

Doing away with the chicken and adding broccoli made a wonderful vacation lunch in California.

#Giambroc

##Ingredients
1 bunch broccoli, cut into florets  
1 red bell pepper, cut into strips  
1 sweet onion, cut into slivers  
2-3 medium size potatoes, cut into 1" cubes  
1 Hillshire Farms packaged kielbasa or chicken smoked sausage (or really any pre-cooked sausage)  
Olive oil  
Salt & Black pepper  

##Method

Pre-heat oven to 475.

Put the potato cubes in a microwave-safe dish with 1/4 cup water, cover and microwave for 5 minutes.

While that happens, using a paring knife, cut the onions and peppers into rough strips, directly into a roasting pan. Add the potatoes. Add the florets on top, then tear the sausage into pieces and scatter over the broccoli. Drizzle with olive oil, not too much salt, and generous pepper.

Roast 15-25 minutes in the oven, stirring intermittently.
cards.name: Giambroc

cards.desc:
I make this frittata every Sunday for M and I to eat all week. It provides 8 wedges which can be eaten hot or cold. It provides a substantial 1.5 servings of vegetables (which you rarely get at breakfast). It provides 100% of your vitamin A, plus more (and better) fiber than a bowl of Cheerios. It also provides enough flavor that you're not choking it down every morning like medicine, which tends to happen with other healthy breakfasts. A much better way to start your day!

Heck, if you want, you can do this Sunday afternoon and have it with salad as a light dinner Sunday night.

#Equipment

Use a 10" round cake pan. Don't pay for nonstick. The parchment is going to take care of that, so nonstick coating is just one more thing to get damaged. Just get a decent aluminum one.  Make a parchment round using [this method][1]. But I make the parchment round as big as possible so it'll line the entire inside of the pan. I wet the paper to get it to stick to the inside of the pan a little, but the weight of the ingredients holds it down well enough.

#Ingredients
9 large eggs (several yolks removed if you want to limit the fat)  
2 10 oz blocks frozen leaf or chopped spinach  
Handful of bacon bits or chopped ham (to taste)  
Handful of shredded cheese (to taste)  
Fresh-ground black pepper  
Salt (maybe)  

**Note**: I make batches of bacon bits and store them in the freezer. Parmigiano or asiago cheese works great for adding a lot of flavor without adding much fat. I put chunks in a food processor and pulverize, then store in the freezer as well.

You can discard a couple of the egg yolks before beating them if you're watching your fat intake.

If you're using bacon or a salty hard cheese, you probably don't need to add salt at all.

#Method

Preheat the oven to 300F.

Make your parchment round. Wet it with water and stick it to the bottom of the cake tin.

Unwrap the blocks of spinach and microwave for two minutes in a microwave-safe dish. Break up the frozen parts. Repeat until the spinach is thawed. Alternatively, remove the spinach from the freezer (and its wrapping) some time Saturday and keep it in the fridge.

Put the spinach in a sieve or strainer and press down on it until most of the water is pressed out.

Mix the eggs, spinach, bacon/ham, and cheese. Stir thoroughly. This is especially important with leaf spinach.

Pour into the prepped cake tin and cover tightly with foil. You can also just put an oven-safe plate on top of it.

Bake for 1-1.5 hours. You can pretty much just put it in the oven and leave it alone while you go about the rest of your Sunday night.

Let cool. Run a knife around the edge and turn out. Peel off the parchment, and cut into 8 wedges. Stores well in the fridge for 4-5 days.

**8 Servings**



  [1]: http://www.thekitchn.com/quick-tip-how-to-line-a-cake-p-78450
cards.name: Sunday Frittata

cards.desc:
Tomato Sauce with Butter and Onions

Adapted by smittenkitchen.com from Marcela Hazans Essentials of Italian Cooking



Serves 4 as a main course; makes enough sauce to lightly coat most of a pound of spaghetti

 - 28 oz can Red Pack whole peeled tomatoes or crushed tomatoes
 - 5 tablespoons (70 grams) unsalted butter
 - 1 medium-sized yellow onion, peeled and halved across the equator
 - Salt to taste

Put the tomatoes, onion and butter in a heavy saucepan (it fit just right in a 3-quart) over medium heat. Bring the sauce to a simmer then lower the heat to keep the sauce at a slow, steady simmer for about 45 minutes, or until droplets of fat float free of the tomatoes. Stir occasionally, crushing the tomatoes against the side of the pot with a wooden spoon. Remove from heat, discard the onion, add salt to taste (you might find, as I did, that your tomatoes came salted and that you didnt need to add more) and keep warm while you prepare your pasta.
Serve with spaghetti, with or without grated parmesan cheese to pass.
cards.name: Tomato Sauce with Butter & Onion

cards.desc:
These are from Meghan's friend Tracy. She busted a couple dozen of these bad boys out of the oven at her Halloween party just when people were getting hungry. Amazing.

##Sandwiches
1 1/2 lb of good ham, shaved as thin as the deli will go  
1 lb of swiss cheese, grated  
24 Martin's potato dinner rolls, medium  

##Spread

1 stick butter, softened  
3 T dijon mustard  
1/2 small onion, grated on the fine holes of a box grater  
1 tbs Worcestershire sauce  
1 1/2 T poppy seeds
1 T real maple syrup (optional)  
Dash Tabasco or Frank's Red Hot (optional)  

##Method

Mix the spread ingredients well in a bowl, then spread generously on both sides of each roll.

Place a bit of ham and a bit of cheese in each roll. Wrap in aluminum foil and refrigerate.

When folks start looking a bit hungry, pop these in a 325F oven for 20-30 minutes, then distribute.
cards.name: Hot Ham & Cheese Sandwiches

cards.desc:
http://smittenkitchen.com/2008/02/matzo-ball-soup/

#Matzo Balls

 - 1/2 cup matzo meal

 - 2 eggs, lightly beaten

 - 2 tablespoons reserved chicken fat or vegetable oil

 - 1 teaspoon salt

 - 1/4 teaspoon black pepper

 - 2 tablespoons chicken stock or seltzer (which both of our mothers swear by for making the balls extra light)

##For soup

 - 2 to 3 quarts prepared chicken stock
 - 1 carrot, thinly sliced
 - A few sprigs of dill

Mix all matzo ball ingredients in a bowl. Cover and place in the refrigerator for 30 minutes.

Bring 1 1/2 quarts of well-salted water to a brisk boil in a medium sized pot.

Reduce the flame. Run your hands under water so they are thoroughly wet. Form matzo balls by dropping spoonfuls of matzo ball batter approximately 1-inch in diameter into the palm of your wet hands and rolling them loosely into balls. Drop them into the simmering salt water one at a time. Cover the pot and cook them for 30 to 40 minutes.

About ten minutes before the matzo balls are ready, bring prepared chicken stock to a simmer with the sliced carrot in it. Ladle some soup and a couple matzo balls into each bowl and top with a couple snips of dill. Eat immediately.
cards.name: Matzoh Ball Soup

cards.desc:
##Ingredients

 - 6 tablespoons butter, plus 2 tablespoons for sheet pan and baking dish
 - 3 cups milk
 - 1 teaspoon salt
 - 1 cup semolina flour
 - 1/2 cup freshly grated Parmigiano-Reggiano, plus 1/2 cup
 - 4 egg yolks

##Directions

Preheat the oven to 425 degrees F.

Butter 1 cookie sheet with 3/4-inch sides and a baking dish.

In a 3 to 4-quart saucepan, heat to scald the milk, salt, and 6 tablespoons butter. Pour in the semolina in a thin stream, whisking vigorously, and cook for about 1 minute, switching to a wooden spoon as it thickens. Remove from the heat and stir in 1/2 cup grated cheese and 4 egg yolks. Mix well to combine. Pour the semolina onto the buttered cookie sheet and, using a spatula, spread to a thickness of 1/2-inch. Allow to cool.

Using a pastry cutter or water glass, cut 3-inch quarter moons out of semolina. Arrange the moons so that they are leaning up against one another (overlapping) in a buttered baking dish and sprinkle with remaining grated cheese. Place in oven and cook 15 to 20 minutes, or until top is deep golden brown. Remove and serve immediately.
cards.name: Gnocchetti alla Romana

cards.desc:
http://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/01/dining/011mrex.html

#Tortillitas With Shrimp
Time: About 20 minutes

##Ingredients
1/2 cup chickpea flour  
1/2 cup white flour  
1/2 teaspoon baking powder  
Salt and freshly ground black pepper  
1/3 cup chopped onion, shallot, or scallion  
1/2 cup raw shrimp, chopped, or scallops or other shellfish or fish  
2 to 3 tablespoons chopped chives, parsley, thyme or cilantro  
Olive oil  

##Method
1. In a bowl, combine flours and baking powder with salt and pepper. Add a little more than a cup of water and stir to combine; consistency should resemble pancake batter (if batter is too thick, add more water, a little at a time). Stir in the onions, chopped seafood and herbs.

2. Put a large nonstick skillet over medium-high heat and film its bottom generously with olive oil. When oil is hot, pour in half the batter until it fills center of pan; spread gently with a spoon to form a large pancake.

3. Cook about 3 minutes, or until pancake is set around edges; flip pancake and continue cooking for another 3 minutes, then flip it again and cook for another 30 seconds or so, until it is crisp on outside but still moist inside. Remove from pan and serve immediately, while remaining batter cooks.

Yield: 4 or more servings.
cards.name: Tortillitas

cards.desc:
I like this dish over regular *puttanesca* because I always have trouble opening a can of anchovies and letting it sit in the fridge until six months later when I throw it out. They're optional here. If you have them, use them. Otherwise, the bacon adds the *umami* and the sardines add the fish component that goes so well with olives and capers. 

This is also a more substantial dish than traditional *puttanesca*, which will often leave me hungry later. The sardines give a decent amount of protein, to make this a *primo* and *secondo* in one.

##Ingredients

2 slices thick-cut bacon, chopped (I usually just cut the slices into 1/4" pieces with kitchen shears, right into the pan.)  
1 medium onion, diced  
1/4 tsp crushed red pepper flakes, or 1/2 tsp Aleppo pepper  
2 cloves garlic, minced or pressed  
4 anchovy fillets, chopped (optional)  
1 large can whole plum tomatoes (RedPack or San Marzano)  
1/4 cup mixed olives (cocktail olives with pimentos are just fine)  
1 tbsp capers  
1 15 oz.oval can sardines in tomato sauce  

1 lb. spaghetti  
hard cheese for grating (see **Note**)

##Method

Fry the bacon over medium heat until crispy, then set aside, adding 1 tbsp fat back to the pan.

Add the onions, stir until translucent, then the crushed pepper,  garlic, and anchovies. Cook for 1 minute.

Add the can of plum tomatoes and mix everything well. Reduce heat and bring to a simmer. While that's happening, poke each tomato with a paring knife a few times (to make the next step safe). 

Go to town with a potato masher to break up the tomatoes. Simmer 20 minutes, then skim the orange foam from the top of the sauce.

Mix in remaining ingredients, breaking up the sardines with the back of a spoon, but leaving some nice substantial chunks.

**Note:** I've had mixed luck with oval canned sardines. Usually, the bones in the fish have become softer like the bones in canned salmon. These are actually good for you! But I've gotten at least one can where the bones were still rather sharp and unpleasant. You might want to pull out a sardine and split it in half to see if the bones are softened, and, if not, use another brand. I'll post what brands work for me later.

Serve over spaghetti with grated cheese.

**Note:** Italians have an imperious rule that you should never, ever add cheese to dishes containing fish, seafood, or wild game. But to me and others, it seems more associated with their idea of being refined than it is with any rules of good eating or taste. In fact, the Chileans make a practice out of violating this rule with their awesome dish *machas parmesanas*, razor clams with cheese.

You've already broken so many hidebound rules of Italian cooking that you might as well go one step farther and add grated pecorino romano, ricotta salata, or parmigiano to this dish. Any of them work.
cards.name: White Trash Puttanesca

cards.desc:
This recipe seems to be mostly method, but it's actually mostly **strategy**. It's a way to have everyone at the table to experience the evanescent wonder of *carbonara*, rather than faffing about with forks and napkins and getting settled.

You need to eat this as soon as it hits the table. The magical moment when the sauce is thickened but not yet absorbed into the pasta is essential. If you're not quick about it, the pasta will eat the sauce for you, and you'll be left with dry noodles.

Be strategic. Serve a course while the pasta is cooking so that people are at the table.

##Ingredients
1-1.5 oz pancetta per person, bacon is fine, but see below  
1 egg per person + 1 egg "for the pot", freshest possible  
1/4 lb dry pasta per person (fresh will not absorb correctly)  
1/4 c grated Parmigiano Reggiano per person  
Lots of black pepper (my taste)  
Salt (for the pasta water only)  

##Method
Salt your pasta water and put on to boil. Make sure to use a lot of water for this recipe.

For the sauce to come out the right texture, your eggs **must** be at room temperature or slightly warmer. If your eggs are stored in the fridge, cover them in hot tap water now and set aside until needed. Better yet, when you buy the eggs and decide to make carbonara, never put them in the fridge. They'll be fine.

Chop pancetta. In a pan large enough to accommodate all the pasta once cooked, fry until well browned. If using bacon, pour off half the fat.  Otherwise, reserve all the fat. It's used to flavor the pasta, but also to coat it, preventing it from absorbing the sauce too quickly.

Leave the pan on the stove with the heat off. 

Crack and beat the eggs very well with generous black pepper. There should be no strings of white in the eggs. Cover and set aside.

Have the grated Parmigiano at the ready.

You can now relax. The whole shebang can be put on hold until later. Put the pasta water on a gentle boil and go about your evening.

When you serve your antipasto or salad, turn the water on high, add your noodles, and stir well. Use a consistent type of pasta and time your boil.

When water comes to boil, place pasta in pot and cook until a bit past *al dente*. *Al dente* pasta is generally preferred for other recipes, but in this case, it'll absorb the delicate sauce and you'll be left with dry (but tasty) noodles. If your dish ends up too dry, add another minute of pasta cooking time.

Right before the pasta comes off, I usually ladle some hot pasta water into each of the serving bowls to warm them.

Reheat the pancetta pan over medium heat.

Make sure everyone has wine and water and everything they need.

Using tongs, transfer the spaghetti from the pot to the pan.
Toss well with the pancetta and its rendered fat, on heat. Add a touch of pasta water and scrape the pan. This will take the browned bits (*fond*) off the bottom of the pan.

Take off heat. Pour in the eggs and stir vigorously until well-distributed. Do the same with half the cheese. If it still seems soupy, have patience. Put the lid on and wait 30 seconds, then stir again. **Do not reapply heat.**

Transfer to warmed bowls and sprint to the table. Do not take pictures to send to your friends to make them jealous.

Serve immediately. Eat immediately. Resume conversation.
cards.name: Spaghetti Carbonara

cards.desc:
Serves 10 to 12
prep time 60 to 90 minutes

    2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil (or panceta)
    4 leeks, white and pale-green parts only, halved lengthwise, cut into 1-inch pieces, and washed well
    3 celery stalks, cut on the bias into 1/2-inch-thick pieces
    3 medium carrots, cut into cubes
    2 garlic cloves, crushed
    2 pinches of red-pepper flakes
    Coarse salt and freshly ground pepper
    5 1/4 cups homemade or store-bought low-sodium chicken stock
    1 1/2 cups water
    1 bay leaf
    1 small (1 to 1 1/2 pounds) butternut squash, peeled and cut into cubes
    2 Yukon Gold potatoes (about 12 ounces), cut into cubes
    1 head escarole, cut into 1-inch-thick ribbons
    1 can (15 ounces) chickpeas, drained and rinsed
    salt and pepper

    Heat oil in a large Dutch oven or stockpot over medium-high heat. Cook leeks, celery, carrots, garlic, red-pepper flakes, and 1 teaspoon salt, stirring occasionally, until leeks are translucent, about 5 minutes. Add stock and water, and bring to a boil.
    Add squash and potatoes. Return to a boil. Reduce heat, and simmer, partially covered, until vegetables are tender, about 15 minutes. Stir in escarole and chickpeas, and return to a boil.  Season with salt and pepper.
cards.name: Winter Vegetable Soup

cards.desc:
Meatless Chili

1 tablespoon olive oil
1 medium onion, chopped
1 cup chopped green bell pepper
1 cup chopped red bell pepper


2 cloves garlic, minced
2 tablespoons chili powder


1 28 oz can whole peeled tomatoes with liquid, chopped
2 15 oz cans kidney beans, drained and rinsed
1 15 oz can white hominy, drained and rinsed
1 (11 ounce) can whole kernel corn, drained and rinsed OR better, 1 10oz box frozen sweet corn
 
1 tablespoon ground cumin
1 1/2 teaspoons dried oregano
Generous grinding black pepper

Low sodium chicken or veg broth (or homemade, or maybe try miso?)
Heat the olive oil in a heavy pot.  Add the onion and stir until translucent, then add the peppers and stir until soft.

Add the garlic and chili powder and stir for 30 seconds.

Add the canned ingredients, the dried herbs, and fill with broth until covered by about 1/2"

Simmer 30 minutes and serve with cheese and sour cream.
cards.name: Vegetarian Chili

cards.desc:
I became aware of enfrijoladas from an NPR story about comfort food that came out [right after the economy tanked](http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=97011416).

They're a great, fast dish, but I've found that, for the processed ingredients in the recipe, brand matters. If you can't get Hot Bread Kitchen tortillas, use the best you can get. They're still cheap. Amy's refried beans with green chile are broadly available and, in my estimation, the best for this and for 7 layer dip.

##Ingredients
1 can refried beans, Amy's with green chile preferred  
Stock or stock cube. Porcini mushroom or Better 'n' Bullion preferred  
1 package of 12 white corn tortillas, Hot Bread Kitchen preferred  
1 medium yellow or white onion, chopped
2 tsp olive oil    
2 10 oz. package frozen leaf spinach (or copious amounts of fresh kale or spinach from market or garden)  
2 chicken breasts, a sliced block of extra-firm seasoned tofu, or a couple of big portobello caps  
Cheese for topping  
Salsa and sour cream  

##Method
Preheat oven to 350.

Empty the bean can into a medium saucepan over medium heat. Add stock cube or paste. Add 2 cans of water to the pot; this will also rinse out the inside of the can. Stir to combine and leave to cook over medium heat, stirring occasionally.

In a skillet, cook the onion in olive oil over medium heat until translucent. Then add your washed greens or spinach. Stir gently. Season with a little salt and When it has come up to a simmer, lay your chicken/tofu/mushroom on the top of the greens, cover, reduce heat to medium, and cook for 8 minutes.

Remove and cube protein. Don't worry if the chicken is a little pink still. It will cook more. Mix cubes with the greens.

Working two at a time, drop tortillas into the thin bean mixture to soften (20-30 seconds). When they've softened, remove with tongs and lay next to each other in one end of a 9" x 13" baking dish. Put a dollop of greens and protein in the center of each tortilla, fold over and push them both to the end. Repeat five more times so you have six rows of tortillas. You'll notice the bean mixture becoming thicker as this goes along. That's good.

When assembled, pour all of the remaining bean mixture over the whole shebang, top with grated cheese, and put in the oven for 30 minutes.

Serves 4.
cards.name: Enfrijoladas

cards.desc:
Spice mix
2 t coriander
1" cinnamon stick
3 dried red chilis
4 cardamom pods
3 cloves
1 t fennel seed
1 1/2 t cumin seed
1/2 t black peppercorns

Stew
Neutral oil (canola, etc)
2.5 lbs lamb stew meat
4 medium carrots
2 medium onions
3 cloves garlic
1 T minced ginger
1 T apricot jam
1 T tomato paste
1 t turmeric
salt

Toast all spices in a pan, then grind in a dedicated grinder or mortar and pestle, set aside.

Heat the oil over medium heat in a heavy pot. Brown lamb in batches, setting browned cubes aside in a bowl. Add oil as needed to keep the pan from drying out and the browned bits from blackening. Don't worry about overusing oil here; if you use too much, it'll float to the top of the stew later and you can skim it off. After last batch is browned, pour the collected juices and fat from the bowl back into the pot. Stir and cook until the juices concentrate and brown, then add onions.


Stir onions until translucent, then add garlic and ginger. Stir 30 seconds  Then add spice mix. Stir and cook for a minute.

Add lamb back, then add all remaining ingredients. Add water to cover all ingredients.

Bring to a boil, stir, then reduce heat to low and simmer 45-60 minutes or until lamb is tender.
cards.name: Lamb Curry

cards.desc:
Prep time = 30 mins
Cook time = 90 mins
Creates 6 servings

4 shallots, finely chopped
2 Tbs butter
1 8 oz pkg white mushrooms, roughly chopped
Generous pinch of cayenne pepper
1/4 tsp ground cinnamon
1/2 tsp allspice, ground in a pestle and mortar
A few scrapes of freshly grated nutmeg

3 carrots, peeled and grated
2/3 cup lentils
The zest of a lemon
the juice of 1/2 a lemon
2 1/2 cups vegetable stock
1/2 tsp Veg beef stock
1/2 tsp marmite
12 grinds of black pepper
2 tsp coconut oil

Small bunch rosemary, leaves stripped and finely chopped
Small bunch thyme, leaves stripped
2 tbs peanut butter or ground hazelnuts
 pinhead oatmeal
1 egg (optional)

In a medium-sized casserole, cook the shallots in the butter until very soft. Add the mushrooms and saut until they've released their water and started to brown. Add the spices, carrots, lentils and lemon zest, and pour over the vegetable stock until the ingredients are just submerged.  Add nut butter, marmite, veg beef powder, pepper.  Season to taste.
Simmer, covered, until the lentils are soft  about 40 minutes.

 Add a little more stock if you think it's needed, but remember that the point of the oatmeal is to absorb the last of the liquid so you're left with something relatively firm. Stir over a low heat until the oatmeal has plumpened. Add the lemon juice, then taste and correct seasoning  be quite generous with the salt.*

let the haggis cool completely, then beat an egg and stir it thoroughly into the mix.  spoon into buttered muffin tins.

bake at 350 for 30 mins, until a crust has formed.
cards.name: Vegetarian Haggis

cards.desc:
My friend Cristin, from Queens, NY, stunned me one night at Bamonte's, a weapons-grade Italian joint in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. She ordered off-menu on her first time there. She asked if they had Chicken *Giamboc*, and they dutifully delivered a "jumble" of roasted chicken, sausage, peppers, onions and potatoes.

Replacing the chicken with kielbasa and adding broccoli made a wonderful vacation lunch in California.

#Giambroc

##Ingredients
1 sweet onion
1 red bell pepper
1 bunch broccoli
1 Hillshire Farms packaged kielbasa or chicken smoked sausage (or really any pre-cooked sausage)  
optional: 2-3 medium size potatoes, cut into 1" cubes  (or 1 sweet potato)
Olive oil  
Salt & Black pepper  

##Method

Pre-heat oven to 475.

Put the potato cubes in a microwave-safe dish with 1/4 cup water, cover and microwave for 5 minutes.

Meanwhile, cover a half-sheet pan with heavy duty foil (the 18" kind, so that it completely covers the whole pan). Don't worry about getting it wrapped too much around the edges of the pan, because you're going to gather the foil together into a packet later. Rub the middle of the sheet of foil with olive oil.

You can pretty much cut the vegetables with a paring knife directly onto the foil. Cut the onions first, cutting them into strips, the peppers on top of them, also in strips, and then the broccoli, in florets.

Drain and add the potatoes, then tear the sausage into pieces and scatter over the top. Drizzle the whole thing with olive oil, not too much salt (because the sausage is salty), and generous pepper.

Roast 8 minutes in the oven. I like to leave it until the broccoli flowers get a little black. Take out of the oven, and gather the edges of the foil sheet together to make a packet.

Roast another 8 minutes.

Be careful opening the packet, as steam will escape out of the top and could burn you. The safest way is to use two forks to rip open the top and let the steam escape.

Serves 2-3.
cards.name: Giambroc

cards.desc:
This is a great way to add veggies to a grilled meal without adding *any* substantial prep time.

##Ingredients
2 heads romaine, brown end of stem trimmed, halved lengthwise  
Olive oil  
Salt and Pepper  
Balsamic vinegar  

##Method

Rinse the halved romaine under the tap. Don't worry too much about shaking all the water out. The water left in there will help it cook.

Season the cut side with salt and pepper, drizzle with olive oil.

Grill, cut side down, on a very hot grill, for about 2 minutes or to taste. Sprinkle with balsamic and serve.

**Asian Variation (untested)**: Oil with toasted sesame oil. Sprinkle with fish sauce. Grill. Season with lime and something spicy (Aleppo pepper, chili oil, Sriracha).
cards.name: Grilled Romaine

cards.desc:
#Ingredients

##Slaw
1 medium head green cabbage  
1 medium head red cabbage  
6 large carrots, scrubbed or peeled  
1 bunch chopped fresh flat-leaf parsley  

##Dressing
1 cup mayonnaise  
1 cup whole milk yogurt
1/4 cup Dijon mustard  
2 tablespoons whole grain mustard  
2 tablespoons apple cider vinegar  
1 teaspoon celery seed  
1 teaspoon kosher salt  
1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper  

1 1/2 cups (6 ounces) crumbled blue cheese  

##Method

Shave the cabbage in a food processor using the thinnest slicing disc. If you maintain firm, gentle pressure on the cabbage, it'll slice better.

The carrots are better done on the large holes of a box grater, but the grating disc of the food processor will do well, too.

Mix the vegetables.

In a medium bowl, whisk together all dressing ingredients. Toss with vegetables. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate for an hour or more to allow the flavors to meld. 

Serve cold or at room temperature.

Makes enough for a barbecue with 25 or so guests, with leftovers.
cards.name: Bleu Cheese Cole Slaw

cards.desc:
This is a staple food in my native South Africa. It's famous for being Nelson Mandela's favorite dish. It's usually enriched with pan drippings and fat from roast meat. I've replaced those with soy sauce and butter to make it both vegetarian and brainless to put together.

This is a super-easy crowd-pleaser side dish.

##Ingredients

2 15 oz. cans white hominy, drained and rinsed  
1 15 oz can of beans (canellini, butter, Great Northern), drained and rinsed (or 1/2 lb dried beans, cooked separately).  
1 T soy sauce  
3 T butter  
1/2 tsp fresh ground black pepper  
3/4 cup water  

##Method

Combine all ingredients in large saucepan over medium low heat.

Simmer 20 minutes, stirring occasionally.

**Note:** If the dish sits for a while, it will continue to absorb water. Add water and reheat at serving time to make sure it's a little saucy.
cards.name: Samp & Beans

cards.desc:
I like my ratatouille very simple. No garlic. Minimal seasonings. Just the basic ingredients.

#Ingredients
2 T olive oil  
1 large sweet onion (Maui, Vidalia), 1/2" dice  
1 large red bell pepper, 1/2" dice  
1 medium zucchini, 1/2" dice  
1 large eggplant, 1/2" dice  
1 14 oz. can diced tomatoes  
Fresh thyme (optional)  
Salt and fresh ground black pepper  

#Method
In a heavy, nonreactive pan, saute the onions and peppers in olive oil over medium heat.

When they've softened, add the remaining ingredients. Leave over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until bubbles start coming up and the veggies start to settle down. Stir gently, reduce to low, and simmer 15 minutes.

Serve as a side vegetable or tossed with orecchiette and Parmigiano Reggiano.
cards.name: Ratatouille

cards.desc:
##Ingredients
1 head romaine lettuce, finely chopped  
1/2 cup cooked chick peas  
1/2 cup cooked red beans  
1 red bell pepper, diced  
1 English cucumber, diced  
2 medium tomatoes, diced  
3 tbsp red wine vinegar  
1 tbsp Dijon mustard  
1 tsp sugar  
1/2 cup olive oil  
Salt and freshly ground pepper

##Directions
Toss all salad ingredients together in a medium bowl. Mix together the vinegar, honey, and mustard. Slowly whisk in the olive oil and season with salt and pepper to taste. Dress the salad with the vinaigrette and serve.
cards.name: Chopped Salad

cards.desc:
I made these for the first time in June 2012, for my nephew Will's graduation party. I didn't have any specific instructions for the two packages of baby portabella mushrooms, so I trimmed them, drizzled with butter, and roasted them in a 425F oven. I put the results in a bowl and stole some leftover toasts from the bruschetta I'd made to decorate it. People were dunking the toast in the buttered mushroom broth and popping a mushroom cap on top, then munching the whole thing. A total hit.

It was really, really good. Below is a first pass at making a streamlined version.


##Ingredients
2# baby bella or cremini mushrooms  
1 stick butter  
1/2 tsp Worcestershire sauce  
Salt and pepper  

1 loaf crusty bread, cut into 1/2" slices  
Olive oil  

##Method

Wash mushrooms well. Remove stems. Put stems in one microwave safe dish. Put caps, butter, and Worcestershire in the other. Microwave both dishes (uncovered) for n minutes or until the mushrooms soften significantly.

Pour the broth from the stems dish into the main dish and discard the stems.

Drizzle slices of bread with olive oil and toast under the broiler.

Serve and stand back.
cards.name: Mushrooms a la Will

cards.desc:
I get yearly emails from my veggie friends asking for this gravy recipe. It's basically just commercial soup rethickened with a rich roux.

##Ingredients
1 box Imagine Creamy Portobello Mushroom Soup  
2 tablespoons flour  
1/4 stick of butter  
bay leaf  
Whatever fresh herbs are available, parsley stems work well, too  
salt & pepper  

##Method

Warm the soup in the microwave or in a separate pot. This is essential to prevent the roux breaking (oil) or clumps forming.

In a medium saucepan over medium heat, heat the butter until it foams and the foam subsides.  Add the flour and stir, cooking until the flour starts to turn tan/beige and raw flour smell disappears.  Add about a quarter of the warm soup, whisking vigorously to break up lumps.

Stir slowly as sauce thickens.  Add bay leaf, herbs, lots of pepper.

Bring up to a simmer. Add more soup as sauce simmers until
desired thickness is achieved, then simmmer about 10 minutes for flavors to meld. If it overthickens or gets gloppy, just thin it with more soup. You will probably not use all of it.
cards.name: Vegetarian Mushroom Gravy

cards.desc:
2 sticks butter  
3 medium yellow onions, peeled and diced  
1 head celery, trimmed and diced  
1 bunch chopped flat-leaf parsley (stems reserved for soup or stock)  
1 cup chopped fresh sage leaves  
Salt and pepper to taste  
1 fresh 1 lb. loaf sourdough bread, crust cut off and cut into cubes  
1/2 cup vegetable or chicken stock  

##Method
Preheat oven to 350. Melt butter in large, heavy pot or skillet over medium-low heat.

Add onions and cook over medium-low heat, stirring occasionally until soft, about 10 minutes.

Add celery, cook 5 minutes longer.

Turn out onion-celery-butter mixture into large mixing bowl. Add bread crumbs, sage, parsley, salt & pepper and toss until well-coated.

Pour stock over stuffing a little at a time, tossing to avoid sogginess.

Bake in a hot, buttered baking dish at 350 for 30 minutes or until golden-brown on top.
cards.name: Sourdough Sage Stuffing

cards.desc:
cup freshly squeezed lemon juice

 

4 large eggs



2 large egg yolks

 

1  cups sugar

 

 cup (1  sticks) unsalted butter, at room temperature, cut into tablespoon-sized pieces

 

2 teaspoons finely grated lemon zest (optional)

 

 

 

        Place all the ingredients except the butter and lemon zest in the top of a double boiler or heatproof bowl. Whisk together just enough to break up the eggs, and add the butter. Place over the bottom of the double broiler or a saucepan that is filled with enough hot water to just barely touch the bottom of the bowl. Place the water over medium heat and bring the water to simmer.
 

       Prepare an ice bath, in advance, in a bowl large enough to hold a bowl you will strain your lemon curd into after you cook it in the next step. This will help chill it faster and prevent the egg from overcooking.    
 

        Cook, whisking frequently, until the mixture reaches 180 degrees on a thermometer. (Time may vary, but it will take around 15-25 minutes, maybe longer.) When done, the mixture will have thickened and will form soft mounds when dropped from a spoon. Remove from heat and strain through a medium-fine mesh sieve into a bowl. Stir in the optional lemon curd. Place the bowl in the ice bath to cool, not allowing the water to come in contact with the curd. Stir/scrape constantly with a spatula, so the mixture cools evenly. After cooling, cover plastic wrap directly on the surface of the curd, making sure there are no air pockets. This prevents the top of the curd from hardening which would mess with the curds smooth texture.
 

       Refrigerate until the lemon curd is cold and firm, usually overnight. May be made up to a week ahead.
cards.name: Lemon Curd

cards.desc:
Granny's Trifle
Make 2 cups of Creme Anglaise (you can find that as the first part of my gelato recipe SST) or for a quick trifle make it with Birds Custard powder or an instant vanilla pudding.

Spread strawberry jam onto Angel Food Cake or Pound cake and place 1 inch cubes in the bottom of big glass bowl.

Sprinkle it with cream sherry

Drain a can of sliced peaches, cut into chunks and spoon them onto the cake. if desired sprinkle walnuts in  too(depends on your taste but granny always did this) save some walnuts for the top.

now pour the creme anglaise on top of everything for best results cover and place in refrig for 24 hours. before serving. 

Cover with whipped cream and decorate with walnuts and
in granny's case always marachino cherries!!

I will give you a more precise recipe if you want, but this may be
enough for you to go on. ( a lot of traditional trifles have jelly in
them but for granny that was a big no no and very "common"!!)
cards.name: English Trifle

cards.desc: http://richcooks.blogspot.com/2011/09/bastardized-rum-drinks-part-1-papazerac.html
cards.name: The Papazerac

cards.desc:
Recipe: Ramos Fizz

1 tablespoon superfine sugar

3 drops orange flower water

Juice of half a lime

Juice of half a lemon

1 1/2 ounces gin

1 egg white

2 ounces milk

Seltzer.

1. Pour everything but seltzer into cocktail shaker in order given. Add big handful of cracked or coarsely crushed iced. Shake steadily until you feel and hear cocktail start to thicken, about a minute.

2. Strain into highball glass and top with splash of seltzer.

Yield: One fizz.
cards.name: Ramos Gin Fizz

cards.desc:
My mom's recipe, from her friend, Dottie Sbarra, of whom I have fond memories.

1 quart apple cider  
1 pint orange juice  
1 pint pineapple juice  
2 tbs. lemon juice  
1/4 cup brown sugar  
1 stick cinnamon  
1 teaspoon butter  
3 whole cloves OR a good grating of nutmeg  
One long strip orange peel  
1 cup dark rum
cards.name: Wassail

members.bio: Hi! I work at Trello. Twitter: @hamidp

old.name: Bleu Cheese Cole Slaw with Whole Grain Mustard
